Some 26 banking stocks — most of them smaller and thinly traded banks — marked new highs Friday. The retail and finance sectors were next in line with five new highs apiece. The semiconductors sector…

Apple (AAPL) approached a buy point and most of the FANG stocks rose modestly Wednesday, now six weekdays since the surprise presidential election of Donald Trump — who has had some pointed criticism for the tech industry — sent big tech stocks tumbling before modestly rebounding the past two days.In fact, Apple and the other large FANG internets — Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — had started falling at least two weeks before Election Day (except for Google-owner Alphabet, whose downturn began Oct. 28). All four FANGs had been trading at or near all-time highs, but mixed earnings for Apple, Amazon and Alphabet weighed on the group.But after the election, a sector rotation ensued, with industries such as drugs and banks getting a lift from Trump's win, and techs, alternative-energy and other arenas getting hit.IBD'S TAKE: The biggest tech companies, of course, aren't necessarily the best tech stocks for investors at any given time. Which techs are best? There are tons of opinions and answers when asking that question, but a good source to put on your checklist is IBD's Tech Leaders.But Trump's election-campaign views and expected priorities have good as well as bad connotations for tech industries.William Blair analyst Bhavan Suri summed it up in a research note Wednesday:"Overall, we believe his views on global trade, net neutrality and internet privacy, and immigration could have negative consequences for technology companies, but his tax plan (including reducing the repatriation tax rate to 10%) would be a net positive given the large amount of foreign cash that many technology companies possess."Trump's repatriation tax plan could bring big bucks back to the U.S. for the top five companies with overseas holdings. Besides Apple and Alphabet, the top five include Microsoft (MSFT), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Oracle (ORCL).In his note, Suri was not shy about pointing out what Microsoft, Cisco and Oracle might target with that cash. Microsoft, he said, might go after ServiceNow (NOW), Twilio (TWLO) or Symantec (SYMC). Cisco he sees eyeing FireEye (FEYE), Gigamon (GIMO) and F5 Networks (FFIV). Oracle, he says, might take a run at Veeva Systems (VEEV) or Tableau Software (DATA).In the meantime, Apple, Alphabet, Amazon and Netflix rose for a second straight day. Facebook was the only decliner, falling 0.73% to 116.34, after touching a more than four-month low of 113.55 on Monday.Apple was the big gainer of the bunch on Wednesday, rising 2.7% to 110.04. That was easily its best day since Trump's win, marking its biggest percentage gain since Sept. 14. It is nearing a 118.79 buy point out of a flat base.Netflix stock rose a fraction to 115.17. It's forming a cup-with-handle base, with a buy point of 129.40.Shares of Alphabet and Amazon rose 0.62% and 0.39%, respectively.RELATED:Apple, FANGs Stop The Bleeding Post-Trump

Analysts hiked price targets for Tesla (TSLA) and F5 Networks (FFIV), cut the target for Disney (DIS) and upgraded VWware (VMW).RBC Capital Markets analysts Joseph Spak and Jacob Hughes raised their price target on Tesla to 220 from 210, but kept a sector perform rating, noting uncertainty over the ramp up of its Model 3 vehicle and its acquisition of SolarCity (SCTY).Tesla's earnings and revenue trounced estimates after the close on Wednesday, but that didn't settle big differences between analysts over its future. Baird kept its 338 price target, noting that Model 3 production is on schedule.Tesla shares rose to 213.70 in the morning, but found resistance the 50-day line. By the close shares edged up just 0.6% to 203.50 on the stock market today.Credit Suisse analyst Omar Sheikh trimmed his price target on the media giant to 125 from 128, while keeping an outperform rating. The lower price target reflects a 2%-4% reduction in his earnings estimates for 2017-2018.Sheikh cited the proposed AT&T (T) merger with Time Warner (TWX), which could create strategic challenges for ESPN and raise the cost of bidding for sports broadcasting rights. He also cited lower ratings for NFL games, but doesn't expect the weak start to the year to remain the trend.Disney could grow by buying Twitter (TWTR) or Netflix (NFLX), Sheikh said, but growing organically would be more costly.Disney shares rose 0.6% to 94.02.Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard upgraded the virtualization software leader to buy from neutral, raising his price target to 95 from 79 after VMware topped earnings estimates late Wednesday. FBN Securities raised its target to 85 from 80. VMware has been generating excitement over its new public cloud partnership with Amazon (AMZN).VMware shares rose 3.4% to 75.77. The stock hit 77.98 intraday, briefly topping a 77.09 buy point.IBD'S TAKE: VMware was added to IBD's Swing Trader as an option play early this week after its new partnership with Amazon. Swing trader applies CANSLIM investing rules to short-term trades.Analysts weighed in the networking technology company's earnings after it beat estimates after the close on Wednesday. Piper Jaffray upgraded F5 to overweight from neutral, raising its target to 141. Wunderlich kept a hold rating but raised its target to 130 from 110.Shares jumped nearly 10% to 130.99 intraday to a 52-week high, gapping out past resistance around 127.RELATED:Tesla Q3 Earnings Go Full Throttle, Topping EstimatesVMware Upgraded, Amazon Pact Called Possible 'Game-Changer'

The stock market remained lower Thursday as a jump in interest rates caused the real estate sector to tumble.The Nasdaq reversed lower to a 0.4% loss. The S&P 500 was down a fraction. The Dow Jones industrial average was up a fraction as DuPont (DD) climbed 2% and medical firms Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Merck (MRK) added 1%.Volume was tracking higher across the board.Retail and fiber-optics stocks were among the weakest in the day's trading. Acacia Communications (ACIA) plunged nearly 12% in big volume. Its biggest customer, Chinese telecom equipment maker ZTE, reported Q3 revenue below estimates.Acacia was the hottest stock in the hot fiber-optics industry in August, but since it broke below the 50-day moving average Oct. 10, the stock has been sinking. The group remains No. 1 out of 197, though.Real estate development, mortgage providers and real estate investment trusts were broadly lower. IBD's mortgage industry group skidded 4%; real estate development operations were off 3%.The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note jumped about 10 basis points to 1.87%, a five-month high. Yields in other major global markets also rose. Traders appear to be embracing the growing chance of an interest-rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December.The Real Estate Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLRE), which tracks the new S&P real estate sector, slid 2.6% to the lowest level since March 10.The sell-off in real estate stocks follows weakness in home-improvement stocks this week. A weak outlook and quarterly results from Whirlpool (WHR) was just one in a series of gloomy reports for the industry. On Wednesday, JPMorgan and Wedbush downgraded Lowe's (LOW).Energy stocks were mainly higher, as crude prices rose 71 cents to 49.89 a barrel. Exploration, production and integrated oil & gas industry groups were up about 1% to 2%.A few breakouts were worth noting.VMware (VMW) broke out past the 77.09 buy point of a flat base in heavy trading, but shares soon dipped back below the entry. The cloud computing company beat profit and sales expectations for Q3.Bluecora (BCOR) climbed past the 13.12 buy point of a cup-type base in high volume. But it also faded back into the pattern after clearing the entry. The internet content company, whose businesses include TaxAct tax-preparation software, posted a loss of 24 cents a share but still beat expectations.F5 Networks (FFIV) soared 9.5%, breaking out past a double bottom with a 126.07 buy point. The data center equipment company late Wednesday beat quarterly expectations. Wall Street firms hiked price targets or upgraded the stock in response.RELATED:Acacia Communications Hammered On Customer ZTE's Sales MissF5 Networks Upgraded, Price Target Hiked On Fiscal Q4 Beat Amazon, Alphabet, Lumentum, Gigamon Earnings: What To Expect After Hours

Major indexes didn't do much of anything Monday, but it was a far different story in the oil market as Wall Street had plenty of headlines to digest. At the close, the Dow eased 0.1% while the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 fell fractionally. Small caps outperformed, with the Russell 2000 up 0.3%. Volume fell sharply from Friday's levels. The…

Stocks opened modestly higher Thursday as earnings reports continued to roll out before the opening bell.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 gained 0.2% and the Nasdaq traded up 0.3%.Big-name earnings news powered early action on the stock market today, with the likes of Ford (F), ConocoPhillips (COP), Western Digital (WDC) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) in play.NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) climbed less than 2% as Qualcomm (QCOM) jumped 4%. Qualcomm agreed to buy the Netherlands-based chip maker for $39 billion. NXP, a leading chip supplier to automotive markets, sets up Qualcomm -- primarily a cell-phone chipmaker -- to pursue autonomous driving applications.  Qualcomm is rebounding from its third test of support at the 10-week line since a breakout in July.Tesla Motors upshifted 4% on a big third-quarter earnings beat reported after Wednesday's close. Revenue met expectations and the company topped its delivery targets. Tesla shares have been locked in a weakening consolidation since April.F5 Networks (FFIV) leapt 9% at the open. The network optimization specialist's fiscal fourth-quarter revenue and earnings both topped expectations. Shares broke out past the 126.07 buy point in a two-month double-bottom base.IBD 50 stock Planet Fitness (PLNT) crunched a 3% advance at the open. The gym chain's third quarter sales and earnings easily topped views, and lifted full-year revenue guidance to above consensus estimates.  Shares ended Wednesday up 5% so far for the week, in a bid to retake support at their 10-week moving average.Ford opened 1% lower. The automaker's third-quarter earnings slipped less, revenue fell slightly more than expected by analysts. Ford shares have been in a gradual downtrend since July 2014.ConocoPhillips swung up more than 2% after reporting better-than-forecast third-quarter results. The company raised its production outlook and cut capital spending targets.Western Digital scaled up 5% following a healthy fiscal first-quarter beat reported late Wednesday.Colgate Palmolive (CL) rose 0.5% after missing analysts revenue targets.First time jobless claims continued to tick lower, according to the Labor Department, dipping to 258,000 in the week ended Oct. 22. That was down from the prior week's upwardly revised 261,000 claims, but above consensus projections for a fall to 255,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 253,000, a second straight increase.Orders for durable goods eased 0.1% in September, the Commerce Department said. That reversed August's orders, which the department revised upward to a 0.3% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose 0.2%, topping an upwardly revised 0.1% increase in August, as well as views for another 0.1% increase.September pending home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors roll out at 10 a.m.Narrow losses were the order of business across Asia's markets on Thursday. Afternoon trade in Europe turned mixed, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.3% and Freankfurt's DAX up 0.3%.  Oil futures traded modestly higher, but West Texas Intermediate still lagged below $50 a barrel. Gold climbed a fraction, to $1,270 an ounce. The dollar rose vs. the yen, but slipped vs. the euro. The 10-year yield jumped 4 basis points to 1.83% as bonds eased.A crowded docket of companies, including Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Amgen (AMGN) and many others, will be out with earnings after the close.RELATED:Tesla Q3 Earnings Go Full Throttle, Topping EstimatesConoco Raises 2016 Production Outlook, Lowers Spending GuidanceWill Cash-Rich Google Announce New Stock Buyback With Earnings?

Highflier Gigamon (GIMO) fell Wednesday after two investment banks downgraded the stock, with both citing its high valuation.Shares were downgraded to neutral by D.A. Davidson, which expects the provider of communications network gear  to report in-line Q3 results. Raymond James downgraded Gigamon stock to market perform from outperform, while also mentioning the possibility that the company could become an acquisition target for network-gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO).D.A. Davidson also downgraded A10 Networks (ATEN) to neutral, following its stock run-up. A10 Networks competes with F5 Networks (FFIV) in the application delivery controller (ADC) market.Mark Kelleher, a D.A. Davidson analyst, downgraded Gigamon from buy, but he still raised his price target to 59 from 54.Gigamon stock closed down 6% at 51.81 in the stock market today. Shares touched a record high of 56.38 on Sept. 27, at that point having doubled in less than seven months. It's currently No. 3 on the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks over the past 52 weeks."Year-to-date, Gigamon stock has appreciated 110% and is approaching our new 12-month price target of 59," Kelleher said in a research report. "We continue to believe the company's underlying network visibility business is solid, and still anticipate revenue for the September quarter of $79 million (vs. guidance of $78-$80 million) and EPS of 31 cents (vs. guidance of 29 cents to 31 cents)."IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon is ranked No. 1 in IBD's Internet-Network Solutions group, which ranks No. 19 out of 197 industry groups. Private equity firms recently acquired two firms in the group, Infoblox and Rackspace Hosting. Gigamon has been viewed as a takeover candidate by some Wall Street firms, with Cisco Systems mentioned as a possible buyer. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Milpitas, Calif.-based Gigamon has expanded into security from its first-market, communications-network hardware appliances that analyze and manage data traffic. Security products now account for about 60% of its total sales."We downgrade our rating on Gigamon ... based on a combination of valuation and scenario analysis of the financial model; this is not a call on the quarter," Raymond James analyst Simon Leopold wrote in his research note. "We worry that slowing in the security market affects Gigamon and that the upside prospect from its new hybrid cloud solution takes time to materialize."As for A10, Kelleher edged up his price target on the stock to 11.50 from 11. A10 Networks stock has shot up 51% in 2016."We continue to believe the company's underlying ADC and security business is solid, and still anticipate revenue for the September quarter of $59 million (versus guidance of $58-$60 million) and EPS of a 2-cent loss (versus guidance of break-even to a 2-cent loss)," Kelleher wrote.RELATED:Gigamon Stock Slips After Big Run-Up, One Co-Founder SellsAcacia Hikes Q3 Earnings Guidance Again After Stock Passes Key TestF5 Networks Upgraded; Arista, Cisco Price Targets Hiked

Oppenheimer upgraded F5 Networks (FFIV) to outperform, while Deutsche Bank hiked its price targets on Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Arista Networks (ANET).Oppenheimer analyst Ittai Kidron set a 140 price target for F5 Networks stock, which was near 117.50, up a fraction, in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today."Near term, we see the upcoming product refresh cycle and the introduction of new stand-alone security appliances as key potential revenue growth drivers," Kidron said in a research report. "Longer term, we believe F5 is taking the right steps to sell into public and private cloud environments, drive more security services, and improve automation and manageability to facilitate easier deployments."IBD'S TAKE: Arista Networks is the top-ranked stock in IBD's Computer Networking group. F5 Networks belongs to IBD's Internet-Network Solutions group, where Gigamon is the top-ranked stock. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup. Both Arista and Gigamon are in the latest IBD 50 listing of top-performing stocks.F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers — electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.Separately, Deutsche Bank analyst Vijay Bhagavath raised his price target on two other networking companies. He raised his target on Cisco Systems to 37 from 35 and hiked Arista Network's target to 85 from 80.Bhagavath says Arista's revenue growth in 2017 will meet or slightly beat consensus estimates. He says Cisco might have upside from the U.S. enterprise market and data-center buildouts by internet companies.Cisco stock was down a fraction in late-afternoon trading Wednesday, near 31, after touching a nine-month high of 31.95 on Sept. 2. Arista stock was up 3% late Wednesday afternoon, near 83, after earlier in the day touching a 13-month high above 84.RELATED:F5 Networks Earnings, Sales Edge Views, But Credit Suisse DowngradesIs Arista Ready to Rumble In New Product Cycle?Cisco Gets Price Target Hikes; Job Cuts To Yield Better Margins

Under Wall Street's microscope Wednesday: Macy's (M), Coach (COH), F5 Networks (FFIV), Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and AstraZeneca (AZN).Citigroup upgraded the nation's largest department store to buy from neutral with a 44 price target, applauding it for making the right moves and calling out its "attractive" free cash flow and dividend yield, according to the research republished on Benzinga.Shares rose 1.5% to 35.21 in the stock market today.RELATED:Stock Futures Bounce; Early Risers: Apple, Macy's, SareptaPurse and apparel maker Coach received a downgrade to underweight from equal weight from Morgan Stanley on concerns of the health of its turnaround efforts. Macau gaming revenue rose in August, the first gain in over two years.Shares rallied 3.1% to 58.31 and are now extended past buy range after hitting an entry point of 51.33 at the start of the month.RELATED:Casino Stocks: A Good Bet In A Dicey Market?Las Vegas Sands, Ciena, Ollie's Hit Buy Points As Market StrugglesMacau Gambling Revenues Revive, Lift Las Vegas Sands, Wynn, MGMOppenheimer handed out an upgrade to F5 Networks to outperform from perform. The data center gear maker reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue in July, but some analysts remained concerned over the growth of its new products.Shares closed up 0.9% at 117.94.RELATED:F5 Networks Earnings, Sales Edge Views, But Credit Suisse DowngradesLastly, Exane BNP Paribas downgraded the drugmaker to neutral from outperform.Shares added 1.1% to 33.11.

Stocks were modestly higher in early afternoon trading Friday after dragging through a weak morning. The Nasdaq rose 0.2% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. Both were off about 0.7% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%, boosted by McDonald's (MCD) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH). Both were up nearly 2%. Volume tracked lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Amid leading stocks, Restoration Hardware (RH) was off its session high, but still up 7% after reporting solid Q2 earnings late Thursday. Shares of the high-end furnishings retailer were up nearly 10%. The pullback after puts the stock back below its 50-day moving average.

On the downside, Energy Focus (EFOI) gapped down and plunged 26% after it priced a secondary offering of 3 million shares at 17 each, a 26% discount to Thursday's close. The recent high-flier already tumbled 17% Thursday. The shares are being sold by the company and some shareholders.

Mobileye (MBLY) trimmed a near 8% loss to 2%. Still, shares were still off nearly 15% for the week on comments from noted short seller Citron Research.Stocks were modestly higher in early afternoon trading Friday after dragging through a weak morning. Slower capital spending by telecom companies, particularly AT&T, might crimp revenue growth at F5 Networks (FFIV), says RW Baird, which downgraded the stock to neutral on Monday. F5 Networks stock was down nearly 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 119. F5 stock is up more than 30% in 2014 but has slid 7% since hitting a…
Stocks further perked up late Tuesday and were on track to end a five-session slide. All three of the major indexes have already recovered all of Monday's losses and then some.

Helped by mining and energy stocks, the S&P 500 surged 1.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 1.1% and the Nasdaq gained 1%. Volume was running higher across the board in the stock market today.

Masco (MAS) gapped above its 50-day line and surged 11% after the company topped views earlier in the stock market today. Shares cleared a 25.05 buy point from a flat base. Masco makes Behr paints, Delta faucets and showerheads, as well as Denova countertops.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) rallied nearly 4% to a new high. The stock took out a 191.11 buy point in a flat base. Jazz has cleared several bases since September, but each breakout has not produced big gains.

Becton Dickinson (BDX) rose 2% in fast trade to a four-month high. Shares passed a 149.03 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The maker of medical supplies and devices will report fiscal Q3 earnings Aug. 6. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 20% to $2.01 a share. That would snap four quarters of single-digit growth. In March, Becton Dickinson completed its $12.2 billion buyout of CareFusion.
Leaders down in volume were few, but Ellie Mae (ELLI) has trimmed a 6% loss to about 1%. The stock found support at its 50-day line. It nearly returned to a 67.10 buy point from a flat base intraday.

F5 Networks (FFIV) late Wednesday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that edged views, but growth from new products remains an issue, said Credit Suisse, which downgraded the stock to neutral despite takeover speculation.Seattle-based F5 Networks said revenue for the quarter ended June 30 rose 3% to $496.5 million, with profit up 8% to $1.81 per share minus items. Analysts had modeled EPS ex items of $1.79 and revenue of $495 million.F5 Networks stock rose as high as 124.76, just below a 125.01 buy point, but ended the day at 121.86, up just 0.3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Shares in the data center gear maker have shot up 24% in 2016 despite slowing growth, in part from speculation the company makes an attractive acquisition target.IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon is the top-rated stock in IBD's Internet Network-Solutions group, while F5 Networks is No. 4. Learn more about Gigamon at IBD Stock Checkup.Despite the Q3 beat, Credit Suisse analyst Sami Badri downgraded the stock to neutral. He also did this despite speculation F5 Networks could be acquired by a private equity firm or Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE)."The stock is now trading at our fair valuation of 125, including $1.1 billion of net cash," wrote Badri in a research report. "While we understand there is speculation for a takeout, investors should not rely on this to seek out upside in the stock and (we) point out that mature legacy IT companies are generally taken out between 3-4 times sales, which is where F5 is trading currently."F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers -- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks."Product revenue growth is now flat-to-down based on our estimates, driven by the transition from physical to virtual (software) ADCs as a percentage of revenue mix," added Badri.

F5 Networks (FFIV) stock rose Tuesday on speculation that private equity firm Thoma Bravo might buy the maker of data-center networking gear.Seattle-based F5 Networks reports earnings after the close Wednesday. Analysts estimate revenue will grow 2% to $495 million, with EPS rising 7% to $1.79.F5 Networks stock popped in early June on reports that it hired investment bank Goldman Sachs to explore strategic options. Shares rose 4.1% in the stock market today, closing at 120.60. The stock has shot up 24% in 2016 despite slowing revenue and profit growth, and it's near a 125.01 buy point out of a cup-with-handle base.F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers -- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.IBD'S TAKE: Gigamon is the top-rated stock in IBD's Internet Network-Solutions group, while F5 Networks is No. 4. Learn more about Gigamon at IBD Stock Checkup.Thoma Bravo, which acquired software provider Qlik Technologies this year, is interested in F5 Networks, the New York Post reported.Citigroup, in a June 7 research report, said: "We see potential (F5) buyers as Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), Dell, EMC (EMC), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and private equity."

Microsoft (MSFT) received a higher price target Wednesday after strong fourth-quarter results, Walt Disney (DIS) was downgraded despite box office hits, and analysts started coverage on Chinese firms Baidu (BIDU) and Alibaba (BABA).Microsoft's price target was raised to 60 from 58 at Stifel Nicolaus, and to 62 from 57 at BMO Capital Markets, after the tech giant reported better-than-expected fiscal-fourth-quarter results late Tuesday.Microsoft's Q4 earnings per share jumped 11% to 69 cents, crushing views for a dip to 58 cents. Revenue also came out ahead of expectations, fueled by cloud demand.Microsoft shares gapped up 5.3% to 55.91, close to breaking out of a consolidation that started toward the end of last year.IBD'S TAKE: Microsoft is seeing a big rise in cloud business, but Amazon Web Services is the leader. Amazon has much stronger overall fundamentals and share price performance than Microsft. IBD's Leaderboard premium service has detailed chart analysis of Amazon.Credit Suisse assumed coverage on  Baidu with a 190 price target and outperform rating. The analysts also assumed coverage on Alibaba with an outperform rating and 114 price target.On Tuesday, the Cyberspace Administration of China, China's internet regulator, announced it would investigate Baidu after media reports alleged that illegal gambling websites use the search engine to promote their businesses.Baidu shares fell 0.3% to 160.65 by the closing bell on the stock market today. Alibaba shares finished the day up 2% to 84.42.Walt Disney was downgraded to hold by Stifel Nicolaus.Disney has been having a blockbuster year. "Finding Dory," its sequel to hit "Finding Nemo," set the record for highest U.S. sales for an animated movie.Disney fell 1.3% to 98.22 at the close.F5 Networks' (FFIV) price target was raised to 115 from 110 by RBC Capital. The maker of data-center networking gear saw its shares jump Tuesday on speculation that private equity firm Thoma Bravo might buy the company.F5 reports earnings after the close Wednesday. Analysts estimate revenue will grow 2% to $495 million, with earnings per share climbing 7% to $1.79.Shares gained 0.7% at the close to 121.47.The human resources software company Workday (WDAY) was downgraded to neutral by Citigroup. Workday shares rose 1.1% to 79.82, after falling out of buy range last week.The fast casual cafe was initiated with an outperform rating and 250 price target at RBC Capital. Panera Bread (PNRA) shares climbed 1.6% to 210.04.

The Dow Jones industrial average, riding its longest win streak since March 2013, is looking for its ninth straight advance, as stock futures signal a higher open, fueled by strong earnings from Microsoft (MSFT) and others. Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) threatened to hit a buy point.Dow industrials futures are up 60 points vs. fair value in the stock market today. S&P 500 futures are 7 points higher, and Nasdaq 100 futures are up about 25 points. On Tuesday, the Dow rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 dipped 0.1%, and the Nasdaq composite lost 0.4%.Microsoft rose 4.5% in premarket trading to about 55.50. Late Tuesday, Microsoft reported surprise increases in adjusted earnings per share, with its Azure cloud business doubling over the past year.Microsoft shares are building the right of a consolidation that goes back to the end of last year. Its stock has a potential buy point at 56.87.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) climbed nearly 7% to 718. Intuitive Surgical, maker of the da Vinci robotic surgical systems, reported a 23% EPS gain and a 14% revenue rise late Tuesday.Intuitive Surgical shares have been in buy range since clearing a 654.98 entry point from a flat base in late June. But the stock looks set to be extended after Wednesday's open.IBD'S TAKE: Should you buy a stock before earnings? You could enjoy big gains -- or big losses. Here are strategies to limit your downside risk.IBD 50 stock New Oriental Education (EDU) fell 4% to about 40. New Oriental Education, a for-profit Chinese private language and test prep provider, reported Wednesday morning Q4 profit of 29 cents a share, a penny above Wall Street views. Revenue rose 20% to $394.9 million, slightly above views for the $389.7 million. But it gave weak Q1 revenue guidance.New Oriental has formed flat base with a 43.68 buy point, but it appeared likely to fall below its 50-day moving average at the open.Meanwhile, social networking giant Facebook rose 0.6% to 121.33. That's above a 121.18 buy point in a flat base pattern. But Facebook's chart is not without flaws. Facebook reports earnings on July 27.After the market close, Intel (INTC), Qualcomm (QCOM), F5 Networks (FFIV) are among the companies reporting earnings. Check out earnings previews for Intel, Qualcomm and F5 Networks.

Intel (INTC), Qualcomm (QCOM), American Express (AXP), Mattel (MAT), Mellanox (MLNX) and F5 Networks (FFIV) reported earnings after the close Wednesday.Keep checking back for real-time updates as the results roll out and commentary comes in.Estimates: Second-quarter per-share profit down 4% to 53 cents on 3% revenue growth to $13.542 billion.Results: Intel earned 59 cents, topping, with revenue of $13.533 billion, missing by a hair. It reported gross margin of 61.8% for the quarter."While we remain cautious on the PC market, we're forecasting growth in 2016 built on strength in data center, the Internet of Things and programmable solutions," said Intel CEO Brian Krzanich in a statement.Intel sees Q3 revenue at $14.9 billion, give or take $500 million. Analysts expect $14.66 billion.Intel shares fell sharply in initial after-hours action, but pared losses to about 2%. Intel closed up 1.5% to 35.69 on the stock market today, hitting their highest level since January 2015.Intel is starting to make modem chips for the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7, taking share from Qualcomm.Estimates: Per-share earnings down 2% to 97 cents in Q3 on a 4% slide in sales to $5.58 billion.Results: Qualcomm easily topped consensus views, earning $1.16 a share non-GAAP on sales of just over $6 billion. CEO Steve Mollenkopf highlighted in a release "meaningful progress" with China licensees and strength in its chipset business.Qualcomm sees fiscal Q4 revenue of $5.4 billion to $6.2 billion with EPS of $1.05-$1.15, the midpoints of which are above views for revenue of $5.73 billion and EPS of $1.08.Qualcomm stock rose 5% in early after-hours trading. Shares had closed up 1.2% to 55.82.IBD'S TAKE: As Intel and Qualcomm seek spoils as iPhone suppliers, is Apple stock still rotten? Apple retook its 50-day moving average earlier this month, but it has yet to retake its 200-day. Apple's fundamentals also don't look great. If you're considering Apple or any of its key suppliers, you should go to IBD Stock Checkup for a full review.Estimates: Profit up 7% to $1.79 a share on 2% revenue growth to $495.3 million.Results: EPS was $1.81 and revenue was $496.5 million, beating Wall Street estimates.For Q4, F5 sees EPS of $1.92-$1.95 on revenue of $515 million to $525 million. Analysts expect EPS of $1.92 and revenue of $516 million.The company also announced late Wednesday that Ben Gibson -- a veteran of Veritas, Aruba Networks and Cisco Systems (CSCO) -- would come aboard as chief marketing officer.F5 Networks stock climbed 3% in early after-hours action to 125.10 -- just above a 125.01 buy area. Shares closed up 1% to 121.47.Estimates: Earnings up 37% to $1.95 a share in Q2, and revenue up 1% to $8.4 billion.Results: American Express turned in mixed results, earning $2.10 -- a beat -- but revenue dipped to $8.235 billion, short of views.U.S. consumer services segment revenue, net of interest expense, fell 3% to $3.2 billion on the lack of customer money coming in through Costco (COST), in addition to cash rebates.American Express shares edged higher in late trading. The stock climbed 0.5% to 64.48 at the close.Estimates: Q2 per-share earnings up 11% to 83 cents, with sales up 31% to $212.9 million.Results: Mellanox earned 87 cents ex items on revenue of $214.8 million.Mellanox sees Q3 revenue of $221 million to $227 million, the midpoint of which is short of current consensus of $226.5 million.Mellanox stock fell to 50 in after-hours action, suggesting it will undercut a 50.79 buy point on Thursday. Shares closed down 0.1% to 51.24 in Wednesday's regular session.Estimates: A swing to a loss of a nickel a share, down from prior-year Q2 profit of a penny a share. Revenue down 5% to $936.6 million.Results: Mattel lost 2 cents a share, a narrower loss than expected, on net sales of $957.3 million. Barbie brand sales rose 23%.Mattel rose 4% in after-hours action. Shares closed up 1.4% to 32.83.

Imperva (IMPV) stock rocketed to a seven-week high Tuesday after billionaire Paul Singer's Elliott Associates revealed a nearly 10% stake in the cloud security firm, but Needham kept a hold rating on shares, questioning how much Imperva can pick up the pace later this year.At the close on the stock market today, Imperva stock finished up 12.4% to 45.46, leading IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group, which was up 1%. CyberArk Software (CYBR) climbed 3% to 49.77 and Symantec (SYMC) lifted 2.2% to 20.92.Elliott acquired 9.8% in Imperva stock late Monday, according to a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In the filing, Elliott argues Imperva stock is "materially undervalued."Imperva "operates in a highly strategic area of the technology industry with an attractive competitive position and a compelling product set in both the web-application firewall (WAF) and database activity monitoring markets," Elliott wrote.But Needham analyst Scott Zeller kept a hold rating Tuesday on Imperva stock. Zeller had downgraded shares in May after Imperva's June-quarter sales guidance for $65.5 million to $66.5 million missed views for $70.2 million, although sales would rise a solid 23% vs. last year at the midpoint of Imperva's forecast.For the year, Imperva guided to $304 million to $307 million in sales, up 30%. That would require a major second-half ramp. The consensus of 20 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters models 10.5%, 23% and 20% quarter-over-quarter growth for the next three periods, respectively, to edge the midpoint of Imperva's guidance."We continue to have reservations about the 'back-end loaded' year-end estimates," Zeller wrote in a research report. Europe/Middle East/Africa sales stalled in Q1, prompting Imperva to remove its EMEA head of sales, further risking Q2 and full-year sales.Elliott's guidance could be a boon, Zeller acknowledged. Elliott has been involved with Blue Coat, Riverbed, BMC Software, Qlik Technologies (QLIK), Novell and Compuware.And Imperva is in a sweet spot for cybersecurity spending, which has trudged below 2014-2015 levels."The hysterical buying patterns in security software over the 2014-2015 time frame are showing signs of cooling, and growth rates are showing signs of deceleration," Zeller wrote. But he said that "Imperva remains an attractive asset because of its scarcity value and position in security spending pockets which still get funding."WAF (web application firewall) and database sales comprise about 40% and 45%, respectively, of Imperva's total revenue, leaving a 5% chunk for fast-growing cloud security. No. 2 cybersecurity firm Symantec last week announced an agreement to acquire cloud-security player Blue Coat for $4.65 billion. That deal is expected to close in Q3.Imperva's rivals are few and far between, Zeller notes. It competes minimally with F5 Networks (FFIV) in WAF and faces off with IBM (IBM) Guardium in database security.

Earlier in the stock market today, Greece asked for a new bailout as a midnight deadline for a payment to the International Monetary Fund loomed.

Leading stocks up in heavy trade were few, but Boot Barn Holdings (BOOT) stepped up 6% to a new high on positive actions from analysts. B. Riley started coverage of the retailer with a buy recommendation and placed a price target at 35. Jefferies lifted the stock's price target to 40 from 30.

Earlier Tuesday, the company announced it won an order for body cameras from the Fresno, Calif., police department.

F5 Networks' (FFIV) partnerships with VMware (VMW) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) will boost its competitiveness in key emerging data center technologies, says ISI Group, which upgraded F5 stock on Wednesday.
ISI Group analyst Brian Marshall upgraded F5 to strong buy from a buy rating and set a 135 price target.
F5 Networks, up 35% this year, was up 2% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 122.50, hitting a 27-month high for the second straight day.
F5 stock ranks No. 43 in Wednesday's midweek update of the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.

Seattle-based F5 Networks sells application delivery controllers that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.

Partnerships with VMware and Cisco will boost F5 Networks in network functions virtualization and software defined networking, two emerging data center technologies, said Marshall, who says he met recently with F5 executives. F5 also competes with Cisco in some markets.

"We covered a wide range of topics across our meetings (security, NFV/SDN, competitive landscape) and came away with increased conviction F5 Networks could approach around $7 of EPS in 2015 (based on 15% year-over-year sales growth) if the IT spending environment starts to provide a modest tailwind and F5 Networks continues ramping new solutions," wrote Marshall. He says F5 Networks should also see upside from its push into security products.

While F5 Networks is the biggest maker of ADCs, competition has intensified. Citrix Systems (CTXS) and Riverbed Technology (RVBD) have gained market share selling software-based, or virtual, ADCs that run on low-end servers in data centers. In the hardware ADC market, F5 Networks competes with A10 Networks (ATEN) as well as Radware.F5 Networks' (FFIV) partnerships with VMware (VMW) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) will boost its competitiveness in key emerging data center technologies, says ISI Group, which upgraded F5 stock on Wednesday.ISI Group analyst Brian Marshall upgraded F5 to strong buy from a buy rating and set a 135 price target.F5 Networks, up 35% this year, was up 2% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 122.50, hitting a 27-month high for the second straight day.F5 stock ranks No. 43 in Wednesday's midweek update of the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.Seattle-based F5 Networks sells application delivery controllers that direct data traffic to computer servers. In the hardware ADC market, F5 Networks competes with A10 Networks (ATEN) as well as Radware.

F5 Networks (FFIV) posted fiscal Q3 earnings late Wednesday that beat estimates, as did its Q4 guidance, with an analyst saying an F5 networking product is often replacing a Cisco Systems rival product. F5 stock was up more than 2% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, earlier touching a more than two-year high above 117. F5 is a…

Shares of data center networking gear maker F5 Networks (FFIV) jumped 12.6% to 123.98 on reports that it may put itself up for sale. F5 Network hired investment banker Goldman Sachs (GS) after takeover approaches, Reuters said, citing an unnamed source.It's unclear who might be a possible buyer. They could include networking equipment maker Cisco Systems (CSCO) or IBM (IBM). The Dell/EMC (EMC) entity could also be a player.F5 Networks' single digit revenue growth in recent quarters looks good enough to make it an acquisition candidate to some. F5 Networks, which has a market cap of just above $8 billion as of Tuesday's close, also has lot of cash on its balance sheet.F5 saw virtually all of its gains in the final hour of trading, following the Reuters report. F5 closed at its highest level since August 2015.F5 stock rose fractionally in late trade.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) signaled that more acquisitions may be coming at its “Discover” customer conference this week, say analysts.There’s been speculation that Hewlett Packard Enterprise could acquire an enterprise software company or F5 Networks (FFIV), a supplier of data center gear.Katy Huberty, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, says Hewlett Packard Enterprise’s recent acquisitions have turned out well."While the company is focused on organic innovation, HPE is open to acquisitions similar to 3Par, 3Com and Aruba -- complimentary technologies that can be sold through HP's distribution channel,” Huberty said in a report. “Software-defined and hyperconverged products are a key area of focus with acquisitions potentially focused here.”At Jefferies, analyst James Kisner says Hewlett Packard Enterprise could be in the hunt for Seattle-based F5 Networks. (F5 Networks shot up nearly 13% on Tuesday on a report that it had hired Goldman Sachs (GS) to help review takeover approaches.)“From a strategic perspective, we believe HPE could be a possible suitor,” said Kisner in a report. “HPE’s Aruba acquisition has been doing well. At Discover, (CEO Meg) Whitman noted that the size of potential acquisitions is less of an issue than their valuation. We note that F5 is trading at a similar valuation as Aruba pre-acquisition.”Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz has an underweight rating on Hewlett Packard Enterprise."The Discover customer conference highlighted management confidence in GDP-like revenue growth as the company invests outside the data center in the $25B campus/edge market and machine learning," wrote Moskowitz in a report. "HPE exhibited some flexibility on M&A, as there was commentary suggesting acquisitions can be pursued if done at the right multiples. Given the successes of Aruba, 3PAR, and ArcSight, we think HPE’s M&A track record has enough support to pursue a larger acquisition if it can move the revenue needle."Hewlett Packard Enterprise on May 25 said it would spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), a move that could put pressure on IBM (IBM) to respond, analysts say.HP Enterprise shares finished 1% higher on the stock market today, hitting a record high for a fourth straight day.

F5 Networks (FFIV) stock pulled back Wednesday, a day after shares in the data center gear maker surged 13% to a 10-month high near 125, on a report that the company is up for sale.If Seattle-based F5 Networks goes on the block, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) looms as a possible buyer, says a Citigroup report, though it's not the only possibility on the investment bank's radar.“We see potential buyers as Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Dell, EMC (EMC), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and private equity,” Citigroup analyst Jim Suva wrote in a research report. Privately held broad-based tech provider Dell is set to complete its acquisition of storage systems giant EMC any day now.F5, the leading maker of application delivery controllers — electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers -- has at various times over the years been considered a possible takeover target. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.F5 stock fell 2.9% to 120.35 in the stock market today.Hewlett Packard Enterprise plans to spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), a move that could pressure IBM (IBM) to respond, analysts say.The former Hewlett-Packard Inc. in November completed its split-up into Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which focuses on enterprise hardware, software and services, and HP Inc., which focuses on the PC and printer businesses.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock rose 1% to 19.35 Wednesday, touching a record high for the third straight day. IBM advanced 0.4% and Cisco Systems rose 0.2% while EMC dipped 0.2%.

Stocks finished mixed Tuesday after a morning rally faded. Rising energy prices and a late report that F5 Networks (FFIV) is in talks regarding a possible sale provided the day's excitement.The Nasdaq finished down 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.1% each in the stock market today. Small-cap stocks outperformed. The Russell 2000 rose nearly 0.3%. Volume was also mixed, with the NYSE reporting higher volume but the Nasdaq exchange reporting lower turnover, according to preliminary figures.In the last hour of trading, F5 Networks vaulted 13% with a big volume spike on reports it was in talks with Goldman Sachs (GS) about a possible sale, according to Reuters.Juniper Networks (JNPR) and Citrix Systems (CTXS) also popped on the report.Oil continued to rise. West Texas Intermediate futures for July delivery settled up 79 cents to $50.48 a barrel. That's the first close above $50 for U.S. crude in 11 months. Declining production, along with fires in Canada and terrorism in Nigeria, have combined to double the price of crude since February.Among IBD 50 stocks, 37 were higher and 13 were lower. The best performer was Thor Industries (THO), which reported better-than-expected earnings but missed slightly on revenue. It gapped up on big volume for a nearly 6% gain.How Does Thor Industries earnings and revenue growth measure up with other leading stocks?The Dow was helped by advances for its two energy components, Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). They rose 2% apiece on the strength of oil prices.But Verizon (VZ) was also a big contributor to the Dow's outperformance, popping by more than 2%. Verizon CFO Fran Shammo said at an industry conference that an acquisition of Yahoo (YHOO) would fit nicely into the company's strategy. It also expects a per-share hit to Q2 earnings of 5 to 7 cents because Verizon's recent labor strike required it to pay managers overtime and hire lots of contractors, while new installations lagged.

F5 Networks (FFIV) could be a buyer, not a seller, and might use its sizable cash-on-hand to acquire a data center security  provider, says Pacific Crest Securities.Some analysts have speculated F5 Networks itself could be sold, amid its slowing revenue growth. F5 Network stock has clawed back 7% in 2016 after falling 25% in 2015. But F5 Networks stock was down 1.5%, near 106, in early trading in the stock market today.Brent Bracelin, an analyst at Pacific Crest,  downgraded F5 Networks stock on Tuesday to sector weight.“Going forward, we see an increasing probability that M&A will have a greater role in defining (F5 Network’s) ‘third act,’ particularly given that F5 has excess cash reserves of $1 billion and robust operating cash flows that exceed $600 million annually," he wrote in a research report.Seattle-based F5 is the leading maker of application delivery controllers (ADCs) -- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.F5 Networks has made some small security-related acquisitions, including Defense.Net, a provider of cloud-based security services that help protect websites from large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, as well as Israel-based Versafe, a maker of software that protects Web applications from malware, fraud and phishing attacks.F5 Network’s closest rival in application-based data center security is Imperva (IMPV), analysts say.The so-called perimeter firewall market -- the main type of firewall -- is a crowded field, with Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) among the vendors.Another concern is that F5’s revenue growth might not rebound in 2016, Bracelin said.“The Shasta appliance refresh cycle will not drive a return to double-digit product growth, at least not for any quarter this year, and that there is increasing execution risk with a higher probability of M&A within cloud security,” he added.F5 competes with Citrix Systems (CTXS), as well as Radware (RDWR) and A10 Networks (ATEN).

CLSA started coverage on a host of chip stocks, including some Apple (AAPL) suppliers, trying to separate the wheat from the chaff among Microchip Technology (MCHP), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Broadcom (AVGO), Intel (INTC) and others.CLSA gave a buy rating to NXP, a supplier to Apple and the automotive market, with a 105 target. NXP rose intraday but closed down 0.3% at 84.75 on the stock market today.Broadcom, another Apple supplier, gets an outperform rating from CLSA, with a 165 target. Broadcom fell 1% to 141.17.CLSA gave a buy rating to Microchip with a 58 target. Microchip fell 0.35%.Intel is seen underperforming the market with a 30 target. Intel shares fell 1.35% to 29.98 after closing Monday at 30.39.One analyst thinks Darden Restaurants (DRI) is looking tasty, while another is curbing enthusiasm for F5 Networks (FFIV).Piper Jaffray raised Darden to an outperform with a 78 target. Darden rose 1% to 63.90.F5 Networks got a downgrade to sector weight from overweight at Pacific Crest as shares neared its prior 109 price target. Shares fell 3.3% to 103.83FBR Capital thinks now is a good time to wade back into the oil patch, upgrading Halliburton (HAL) to outperform from market perform and raising its target to 49 from 44. Halliburton rose 2.5% to 41.17, also helped by rising oil prices.

F5 Networks (FFIV) late Wednesday reported mixed fiscal Q2 results and forecast current-quarter profit above estimates, with revenue guidance below views.The Seattle-based data center gear maker said March-quarter EPS minus items rose 6% to $1.68 while revenue rose 2% to $483.7 million. Analysts had estimated $1.63 and $486.2 million.“F5 Networks reported mixed March-quarter results with revenue falling below expectations, but lower taxes and an aggressive share repurchase helped EPS come in better than consensus,” said Troy Jensen, analyst at Piper Jaffray, in a research report.F5 is the leading maker of application delivery controllers (ADCs)-- electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. Top rivals include Cisco Systems (CSCO) (IBD).The company forecasts current-quarter revenue of $495 million at its midpoint, up 2.4% from the year-ago quarter and below. consensus estimates of $503 million. It expects EPS in a range of $1.77 to $1.80, up from $1.67 and above analyst consensus of $1.74 per share.“Management guided revenue below the Street, citing ongoing uncertainty in the macro and IT spending environment and potential pauses ahead of the new product cycle,” said Jason Ader, an analyst at William Blair, in a research report.“Looking beyond the current quarter, even with a product refresh cycle on the horizon, we believe F5 will struggle to grow its product sales on a sustainable basis due to multiple headwinds from a maturing on-premise ADC market, competitive pressure from the public cloud, and a stand-alone security portfolio that has so far been unable to compete effectively in an already crowded security market,” Ader wrote.F5 Networks stock was up 2.5% in premarket trading Thursday, near 96 and just about even for 2016.

Major averages held slight gains in early afternoon trading Tuesday as Wall Street awaited minutes from the July 30 Fed meeting.The Dow industrials, boosted by Boeing (BA) and Home Depot (HD), led with a 0.2% gain. The S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the Nasdaq was fractionally higher. Volume was tracking lighter on both exchanges in the stock market today.On the economic front, the Mortgage Bankers' Association reported home purchase applications slipped 0.4% in the latest week to its lowest level in almost six months. But refinancing activity rose 2.7% amid lower 30-year mortgage rates.Home Depot (HD) climbed 2% to a new high in twice normal trade. Shares surged 6% Tuesday after the home improvement retailer's Q2 earnings and sales topped forecasts. The chain also lifted its full-year profit guidance by a dime to $4.52 a share. The stock is now 8% above an 83.30 flat-base buy point.Rival Lowe's (LOW) pared its losses from a 3% drop after its Q2 results also beat views. But the retailer lowered its full-year sales forecast. The stock is just above a 51.38 cup buy point.F5 Networks (FFIV) surged 2% in heavy trade to its highest level in more than two years. The stock extended a 3% gain from Tuesday, when it finally followed through on a late-July breakout past a 116.81 flat-base buy point. It's now 5% above the entry. ISI Group on Wednesday raised its rating on F5 to strong buy from buy.Among IBD 50 stocks, Trinity Industries (TRN) added 2% in a third straight up session. The stock is now 2% above a 46.39 four-weeks-tight buy point it cleared yesterday, before closing below the entry. Keybanc Capital Markets on Tuesday lifted its price target on the railcar maker to 55 from 53 and raised its full-year EPS estimate by a nickel to $4.15. On Monday, Trinity closed its buyout of Meyer Steel Structures.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.
Wall Street estimates have been falling for F5 Networks (FFIV), along with its share price, ahead of its fiscal Q3 earnings report.
F5 is the No. 1 maker of data center gear that speeds up Web and application servers. It's slated to report results for the June quarter on Wednesday.

Seattle-based F5's stock doubled from early October through early May, but has plummeted nearly 35% since May 3 on worries over slower corporate spending on information technology amid intensifying price competition.
The company's guidance could be key, says Simon Leopold, a Raymond James analyst, in a report.
"While it feels like bad news is reflected in the stock, we worry that a September forecast below consensus could weigh on the shares," he wrote.
He says F5 is likely to meet Q2 estimates, "but we worry that slow spending from its financial and government (customers) weigh on the outlook."

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate that F5's profit will rise 17.5% to $1.14 per share from 97 cents in the year-earlier period. That would be the smallest percentage growth in three years. They see F5's sales climbing 21% to $353 million.

Ryan Hutchinson, analyst at Lazard Capital Markets, says F5 might struggle to hit its guidance of 20% revenue growth in 2012. Spending by its telecom customers seems to be slowing, he says in a report.

"While management has previously noted that it expects the company's (telco service provider) segment to abate somewhat from record F2Q levels (27% of company revenue), our checks indicate that the magnitude of the downtick could be worse than feared," he said. "Given the deteriorating macro environment, we are unsure if strength in F5's other verticals will be enough to offset this weakness.
"We now believe that the company's 20% FY12 revenue target may represent a best-case scenario."
F5 has been pushing into the security market. And based upon a survey of resellers, that's going well, says Piper Jaffray analyst Troy Jensen.
"We surveyed F5 vendors on the impact of the company's new security focus has had on sales and nearly 90% of respondents cited the new focus as a driver of new customer growth," he said in a report.

F5 Networks said it earned $1.26 per share minus items for fiscal Q4 2013, ended Sept. 30, up 12% from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose…
The IPO market is moving at a blistering pace with the average price of new issues this year up nearly 40% from their offering price.
And the 45 initial public offerings completed thus far is double the amount from the same period last year, according to Renaissance Capital. They've raised $7.6 billion, up 28%.

"We're off to a very strong start this year and we think at the beginning stage of a new long-term IPO cycle," said Linda Killian, portfolio manager for the Global IPO Fund at Renaissance Capital, an IPO investment and research firm.

From 2008 through 2012, IPO offerings per year were, on average, less than half of historic norms. That changed in 2013 when 222 IPOs launched, the most since 2004. So far, 2014 is on pace to exceed last year.

IPO market enthusiasm is expected to accelerate now that China e-commerce giant Alibaba Group confirmed it plans to file an IPO on the U.S. market. Though Alibaba did not specify a time, speculation is the filing might come in April. This follows Friday's news that Sina's (SINA) Weibo, a Chinese microblogging service similar to Twitter (TWTR), filed paperwork for its IPO with plans to raise $500 million.

Other high-profile tech IPOs expected this year include cloud storage operator Box and Dropbox, online music provider Spotify, wearable camera maker GoPro, and GrubHub, an online portal for food delivery service.
"All of this brings positive attention to the IPO market and underlines how important it is to equity markets overall and our economy," said Killian.
(Nearly) Double Coupons

Also fueling enthusiasm is the performance of recent tech IPOs. Varonis Systems (VRNS) stock doubled on its first day of trading Feb. 28. Varonis provides software that companies use to get a deeper understanding of data buried within digital files.
Online coupon provider Coupons.com (COUP) rose 88% on its first day of trading March 7.

Last week's four enjoyed an average first-day pop of 48%, according to Ipreo Capital Markets. That included Castlight Health (CSLT), which spiked 149%, the year's best debut after Dicerna Pharmaceutical (DRNA), which jumped 207% on Jan. 30. The next day came Ultragenyx Pharmaceutical (RARE), which rose 101%.
Already four IPOs have more than doubled this year, vs. six in all of 2013, Ipreo said.
The health care sector has dominated the IPO market, with 26 of the 45 thus far this year, primarily in the biotech field.
"The enormous amount of biotech IPOs is a continuation of 2013 but at an even faster pace," said Scott Sweet, senior managing partner at IPOboutique.com.
The downside, said Sweet, is that top-notch biotech IPOs, in the foreseeable future, are already out the door.
"They're getting weaker in quality," he said.
A10 Networks Soon

Ten IPOs are slated for this week. Among those receiving the most attention is A10 Networks, which makes technology that accelerates data center networks. Rivals include F5 Networks (FFIV), Radware (RDWR) and Cisco (CSCO).
IPOboutique says its channel checks reveal that A10 is in strong demand, already multiple times oversubscribed.

Checks also suggest strong demand for Paylocity Holding, a cloud-based provider of payroll and human management software, Q2 Holdings, a provider of cloud-based banking services, and Akebia Therapeutics, a developer of anemia treatment.

Other IPOs this week include international e-commerce services provider Borderfree; Amber Road, a cloud-based provider of trade management software; and Globoforce, a provider of cloud-based social recognition software.

Another five IPOs are lined up for next week. They include King Digital Entertainment, the high-profile maker of the "Candy Crush Saga" online game. King Digital expects to raise $500 million by selling 22.2 million shares in a 21 to 24 range. That would give it a $7.6 billion market cap at the high end.
Alibaba The Big Prize
But the upcoming king of all IPOs is Alibaba. It's expected to surpass Facebook (FB) as the largest-ever U.S. tech IPO in terms of money raised and market value.

Alibaba is China's top e-commerce provider, described as Amazon.com (AMZN), eBay (EBAY), PayPal and Google (GOOG) all wrapped into one. Analysts say its IPO could raise $20 billion and give the company a market valuation of $100 billion to $150 billion.The IPO market is moving at a blistering pace with the average price of new issues this year up nearly 40% from their offering price. And the 45 initial public offerings completed thus far is double the amount from the same period last year, according to Renaissance Capital. They've raised $7.6 billion, up 28%."We're off to a very strong start this year and we think at the beginning stage of a new long-term IPO cycle," said Linda Killian, portfolio manager for the Global IPO Fund at Renaissance Capital, an IPO investment and research firm.From 2008 through 2012, IPO offerings per year were, on average, less than half of historic norms. That changed in 2013 when 222 IPOs launched, the most since 2004. So far, 2014 is on pace to exceed last year.IPO market enthusiasm is expected to accelerate now that China e-commerce giant Alibaba Group confirmed it plans to file an IPO on the U.S. market. The major stock indexes climbed a bit off their session lows but remained sharply lower in early afternoon action.
The Nasdaq composite was down 1.1%, after shedding as much as 1.4%. The NYSE composite fell 0.7%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.5%. Volume was tracking higher across the board.
Cloud-computing plays continued to trade sharply lower in the wake of a disappointing earnings report late Wednesday from F5 Networks (FFIV), which was down 22%.

Riverbed Technology (RVBD) lost 4% in huge turnover. The stock was finding support near its 50-day moving average and has trimmed much of its loss. It had been well-extended after a big advance in the second half of 2010.

Meanwhile, chip designer NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) slid 6% in big trade. The stock sliced through its 50-day line early Thursday but then climbed back above that key level. Earlier this month, NetLogic cleared a 34.45 handle buy point. While it's now just below that buy point, the stock's initial tumble out of the gate Thursday triggered the 8% sell rule for anyone who bought shares at that early January breakout.

On the upside, several companies in the car parts and repairs business were faring well Thursday. Monro Muffler Brake (MNRO) rose 3% in strong turnover. Cloud-computing technology provider F5 Networks (FFIV) hasn't provided many buy points despite a 171% run-up in the past 12 months.

The stock could've been bought out of a four-weeks-tight pattern in October 2009. Since then, it has consolidated around the 10-week moving average several times. But it never formed a legitimate base. The last entry offered was a three-weeks-tight etched in August.

Some winning stocks don't make it easy for the disciplined investor to catch the ride. F5 is such a case. If an investor missed the opportunity in October 2009, the ensuing opportunities were few and far between. But if an investor caught that initial entry, he or she could still be sitting on the shares.
On Tuesday, it marked a new 52-week high in strong volume.
Fundamentally, the stock is strong. Return on equity was 17.7% last year, the best in at least nine years. Pretax margin was 29.6%, up from the previous year.
Annual earnings are expected to grow 45% in fiscal 2010 ended in September and 26% next fiscal year.
Quarterly earnings and sales show acceleration. Earnings grew 22%, 30%, 47% and 65%. Revenue increased 2%, 15%, 34% and 46%.
The Street expects 42% earnings growth on a 41% sales pop when it reports its fiscal Q4 on Oct. 26.
The number of funds holding shares has been essentially flat the past two quarters. But several top-rated funds hold shares.

Reuters reported Monday that F5 Networks was approached by an unidentified company a year ago about a takeover and remains an attractive takeover target for technology giants. The Nasdaq continued to lead with a 0.5% gain, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally lower. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today
